segment.source: Certificate profiles are policies that configure managed devices with the certificates they need so device users can connect to your on-premises company resources using connections like Wi-Fi or VPN.
segment.target: Certificate profiles are policies that configure managed devices with the certificates they need so device users can connect to your on-premises company resources using connections like Wi-Fi or VPN.

segment.source: When you deploy certificate profiles, you provision devices with a trusted root certificate for your PKI, and configure them to request device specific certificates.
segment.target: When you deploy certificate profiles, you provision devices with a trusted root certificate for your PKI, and configure them to request device specific certificates.

segment.source: You can create three types of certificate profiles:
segment.target: You can create three types of certificate profiles:

segment.source: PKCS #12 (.PFX) Certificate Profile: this can be used with Android 4.0 or later, iOS 6.0 and later, and Windows 10 (desktop and mobile) and later.
segment.target: PKCS #12 (.PFX) Certificate Profile: this can be used with Android 4.0 or later, iOS 6.0 and later, and Windows 10 (desktop and mobile) and later.

segment.source: SCEP Certificate Profile: this can be used with iOS 6.0 and later, Mac OS X 10.9 and later, Android 4.0 or later, and Windows Phone 8.1 and later.
segment.target: SCEP Certificate Profile: this can be used with iOS 6.0 and later, Mac OS X 10.9 and later, Android 4.0 or later, and Windows Phone 8.1 and later.

segment.source: Trusted Certificate Profile: this can be used with iOS 6.0 and later, Mac OS X 10.9 and later, Android 4.0 or later, and Windows Phone 8.1 and later.
segment.target: Trusted Certificate Profile: this can be used with iOS 6.0 and later, Mac OS X 10.9 and later, Android 4.0 or later, and Windows Phone 8.1 and later.

segment.source: Examples of when to use certificate profiles:
segment.target: Examples of when to use certificate profiles:

segment.source: Employees must be able to connect to Wi-Fi hotspots in multiple corporate locations.
segment.target: Employees must be able to connect to Wi-Fi hotspots in multiple corporate locations.

segment.source: To do this, you can use certificate profiles to deploy the certificates required to secure the Wi-Fi connection.
segment.target: To do this, you can use certificate profiles to deploy the certificates required to secure the Wi-Fi connection.

segment.source: You have a PKI in place and want to move to a more flexible, secure method of provisioning certificates that lets users access company resources from their personal devices without compromising security.
segment.target: You have a PKI in place and want to move to a more flexible, secure method of provisioning certificates that lets users access company resources from their personal devices without compromising security.

segment.source: To do this, you can configure certificate profiles with settings and protocols that are supported for the specific device platform.
segment.target: To do this, you can configure certificate profiles with settings and protocols that are supported for the specific device platform.

segment.source: The devices can then automatically request these certificates from an Internet-facing enrollment server.
segment.target: The devices can then automatically request these certificates from an Internet-facing enrollment server.

segment.source: You can then configure VPN profiles to use these certificates so that the device can access company resources.
segment.target: You can then configure VPN profiles to use these certificates so that the device can access company resources.

segment.source: Deploy certificate profiles
segment.target: Deploy certificate profiles

segment.source: When you deploy certificate profiles, the certificate file from the Trusted CA certificate profile is installed on devices, and the SCEP or .PFX certificate profile is used by the device to create a certificate request by the device.
segment.target: When you deploy certificate profiles, the certificate file from the Trusted CA certificate profile is installed on devices, and the SCEP or .PFX certificate profile is used by the device to create a certificate request by the device.

segment.source: Certificate profiles install only on applicable devices based on the platform you use when creating the profile.
segment.target: Certificate profiles install only on applicable devices based on the platform you use when creating the profile.

segment.source: You can deploy certificate profiles to user collections or device collections.
segment.target: You can deploy certificate profiles to user collections or device collections.

segment.source: To allow certificates to be published to devices quickly after the device enrolls, deploy the certificate profile to a user group (not a device group).
segment.target: To allow certificates to be published to devices quickly after the device enrolls, deploy the certificate profile to a user group (not a device group).

segment.source: If you deploy to a device group, a full device registration must take place before the device receives policy.
segment.target: If you deploy to a device group, a full device registration must take place before the device receives policy.

segment.source: Although each profile is deployed separately, both the Trusted Root and the SCEP/.PFX profile must be deployed or else the SCEP/.PFX certificate policy will fail.
segment.target: Although each profile is deployed separately, both the Trusted Root and the SCEP/.PFX profile must be deployed or else the SCEP/.PFX certificate policy will fail.

segment.source: You deploy certificate profiles the same way you deploy other policy for .
segment.target: You deploy certificate profiles the same way you deploy other policy for .
